content:
nLab has a section on existence and characterization of (co)limits in a Grothendieck construction.

I believe this refers to the contravariant GC. What is the corresponding theorem for the covariant GC?
There are two references mentioned there which I looked at but couldn't find the answer in them...

You can relate the contra- and covariant grothendieck constructions by ∫coC∈CF(C)=(∫contraC∈CopF(C)op)op\int_\text{co}^{C \in \mathcal C} F(C) = \left(\int_\text{contra}^{C \in \mathcal C^\text{op}} F(C)^\text{op}\right)^\text{op}∫coC∈C​F(C)=(∫contraC∈Cop​F(C)op)op. So using the fact that colimits in C\mathcal CC are limits in Cop\mathcal C^\text{op}Cop. I think you should be able to write down a corresponding version of the existence theorems

For example, this tells us ∫coF\int_\text{co}F∫co​F is complete iff ∫contraFptwise-op\int_\text{contra}F^\text{ptwise-op}∫contra​Fptwise-op is cocomplete, so you get a sufficient condition for ∫coF\int_\text{co}F∫co​F in terms of the cocompleteness of Cop\mathcal C^\text{op}Cop and Fptwise-opF^\text{ptwise-op}Fptwise-op.

Dylan Braithwaite said:

For example, this tells us ∫coF\int_\text{co}F∫co​F is complete iff ∫contraFptwise-op\int_\text{contra}F^\text{ptwise-op}∫contra​Fptwise-op is cocomplete, so you get a sufficient condition for ∫coF\int_\text{co}F∫co​F in terms of the cocompleteness of Cop\mathcal C^\text{op}Cop and Fptwise-opF^\text{ptwise-op}Fptwise-op.

Thank you, Dylan. But I'm still getting confused by all these op's. I am thinking about applying the covariant GC to the same contravariant functor, F:Cop→CatF : \mathcal{C}^{op} \to \mathcal{Cat}F:Cop→Cat,. I'm not sure if your description assumes FFF has domain C\mathcal{C}C or Cop\mathcal{C}^{op}Cop.

So given F:Cop→CatF : \mathcal{C}^{op} \to \mathcal{Cat}F:Cop→Cat, applying the covariant GC I get ∫coC∈CopF\int_\text{co}^{C \in \mathcal{C}^{op}} F∫coC∈Cop​F is complete if

  1. C\mathcal{C}C is cocomplete
  2. F(J)F(J)F(J) is cocomplete
  3. F(f):F(J)→F(K)F(f) : F(J) \to F(K)F(f):F(J)→F(K) preserves colimits

..? I'm really not sure.

I was assuming FFF with domain C\cal CC, since thats the usual data for the covariant GC, but lets step through it with the domain as Cop\cal C^\text{op}Cop.

So for F:Cop→CatF : \cal C^\text{op} \to \sf CatF:Cop→Cat and FpF^\mathrm{p}Fp the pointwise opposite of FFF, we have that the following are equivalent:

  • the covariant Grothendieck construction ∫coCopF\int^{\cal C^\text{op}}_\text{co} F∫coCop​F is complete
  • the opposite of the contravariant Grothendieck construction (∫contrCFp)op\left(\int^{\cal C}_\text{contr} F^\mathrm{p}\right)^\text{op}(∫contrC​Fp)op is complete
  • the contravariant Grothendieck construction ∫contrCFp\int^{\cal C}_\text{contr} F^\mathrm{p}∫contrC​Fp is cocomplete

From the result on the nlab, the Grothendieck construction ∫contrCFp\int^{\cal C}_\text{contr} F^\mathrm{p}∫contrC​Fp is cocomplete if:

  • C\cal CC is cocomplete
  • Fp(C)F^\mathrm{p}(C)Fp(C) is cocomplete for all C∈CC \in \cal CC∈C
  • Fp(f):Fp(C’)→Fp(C)F^\mathrm{p}(f) : F^\mathrm{p}(C’) \to F^\mathrm{p}(C)Fp(f):Fp(C’)→Fp(C) has a left adjoint for all f∈C(C,C’)f \in \mathcal{C}^(C, C’)f∈C(C,C’)

Expanding the definition of FpF^\text{p}Fp, this is equivalent to asking that:

  • C\cal CC is cocomplete
  • F(C)opF(C)^\text{op}F(C)op is cocomplete for all C∈CC \in \cal CC∈C
  • F(f)op:F(C’)op→F(C)opF(f)^\text{op} : F(C’)^\text{op} \to F(C)^\text{op}F(f)op:F(C’)op→F(C)op has a left adjoint for all f∈C(C,C’)f \in \mathcal{C}(C, C’)f∈C(C,C’)

and one more step of simplification:

  • C\cal CC is cocomplete
  • F(C)F(C)F(C) is complete for all C∈CC \in \cal CC∈C
  • F(f):F(C’)→F(C)F(f) : F(C’) \to F(C)F(f):F(C’)→F(C) has a right adjoint for all f∈C(C,C’)f \in \mathcal{C}(C, C’)f∈C(C,C’)

Thank you! :blush: The one example I was looking at is in posets where completeness and cocompleteness is the same, so that didn't help me work this one out besides the 3rd point (has a right adjoint). Interestingly, it did show me that this condition is not necessary, since our (covariant) GC poset is cocomplete but the maps F(f)F(f)F(f) do not preserve limits/have a left adjoint.
Naso has marked this topic as resolved.
